Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will study near-field optics of nanoscale complexes of rare earth ions with DNA-wrapped nanotubes for bio-sensing applications. A new class of rare earth based bio-compatible materials will be explored. In these materials DNA-wrapped nanotube, functionalized with bio-analytes for optical sensing, will serve as a plasmonic nano-antenna. The approach is to apply a theoretical modeling along with an optical characterization, to understand the near-field interaction between nanotube plasmonic modes and rare-earth emitter in the presence of surrounding bio-molecules.
The intellectual merit is in understanding the physics of the near-field electromagnetic modes in the rare-earth/DNA/nanotube complexes, developing schemes for their bio-functionalization and exploring effects of surrounding environment on their near-field response. This will lead to developing new nano-materials and optimizing it for bio-sensor applications on a long run.
The broader impact will include dissemination of accumulated fundamental knowledge to undergraduate and graduate students at Lehigh University as well as to students from other PA Schools via the web-based inter-university network MatPAC. Research results will be disseminated to local industry, via the Lehigh Nanotech Network, and to other Lehigh part¬ners from industry, national labs and academia. The K-12 outreach program will include lectures at local schools in Lehigh Valley and contributions to the exhibition at the National facility ? DaVinci Discovery Center. STEM enhancement programs are planned for teachers from local Community Colleges and Kutztown University. Research will benefit the REU and GAAN programs of the Physics Department, with special attention paid to strong involvement from STEM-under¬rep¬re¬sen¬ted groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Carbon nanotubes have diameters of only a few nanometers, which is comparable to many biological macromolecules such as enzymes, antibodies, DNA plasmids, etc.  This makes them increasingly attractive for applications in biomedical research and health care. In this project use of carbon nanotubes with (non-human) neural stem cells was demonstrated (Fig.3 presents a fluorescent microscopy image which shows nanotubes – red and cyan - inside cells’ cytoskeleton – green – and near the nucleus - blue). This study proved biocompatibility of nanotubes functionalized with DNA or RNA and its potential in nerve tissue engineering. This project provides us with basic knowledge on how the living organisms, at the cell level, may be influenced by modern nanomaterials upon ingestion.

Capability of imaging biological objects depends critically on behavior of optical sensing materials, which was explored using exemplar system of rare-earth ions. These ions were shown to substantially increase their luminescence properties in certain conditions (Fig.2), thus manifesting itself as a good optical nanoscale sensor. Behavior of the ions was further studied in nanoscale compartments of artificial biomimetic gel material. Scanning Electron micrograph of the deoxycholate gel (Fig.1), prepared by two different methods, revealed rich structure of this gel material, similar by complexity to intracellular environment.
